During the past three years, I have been supported by an NSF Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (MSPRF). It has $135,000 in support which ran from 2011 to 2014, and was conducted at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology under the supervision of Professor Jacob Fox. The MSPRF proposal focused heavily on intersection graphs of geometric objects in the plane with applications to graph drawing, and generalizations of the Erdos-Szekeres Happy Ending theorem. Over the past three years, I have written 14 research papers on these topics. I am happy to report that I have solved or made significant progress on all of the problems described in that proposal. In particular I gave new bounds on the chromatic number of intersection graphs of segments in the plane, and in joint work with Walczak, we gave new bounds on the maximum number of edges in a k-quasi-planar graph. Also in joint work with Fox, Pach, and Sudakov, we obtained near tight bounds on several Ramsey-type functions related to monochromatic monotone paths in ordered hypergraphs. This work introduced a combinatorial generalization of the Happy Ending theorem.
Arguably the greatest development over the past three years under the MSPRF was on the theory of semi-algebraic hypergraphs. These developments utilize ideas from combinatorics and algebraic geometry and have a wide variety of deep applications in discrete geometry.
